The surgical specialties of cardiothoracic, neurosurgery, urology, otolaryngology and orthopedics are separate departments with their own trainees, although the general surgery resident has exposure to these specialties as well.   A progressive responsibility is the key element of the NYU residency, with surgical  decision-making and responsibilities taught in clinical and didactic settings.   Residents train at three major hospitals :   Tisch University Hospital   Bellevue Hospital Center   Manhattan Veteran’s Affair Medical Center   Residents at NYU care for patients with a multitude of problems representing the entire spectrum of surgical diseases. From Bellevue’s world-renowned trauma service to the highly regarded tertiary care services at Tisch, NYU surgical residents work under the leadership of eminent faculty.   Nine first-year categorical residents are selected each year to complete the general surgery training program. Additional residents match separately to preliminary positions prior to specialty training. We stand committed to the goal of continuing our long traditional excellence in surgical training.   Our Mission   Our mission is to develop leaders in clinical surgery. The Department of Surgery will endeavor to evolve as a model for primary and tertiary patient care services, integrating all aspects of a case including inpatient, ambulatory, and emergency services.   The faculty will provide the surgical resident with a progressively graded curriculum of study and clinical experience under guidance and supervision. The surgical resident will acquire a broad understanding of human biology as it relates to disorders of a surgical nature and the technical knowledge and skills appropriate to completely manage patients with surgical diseases.       Our Vision   The Department of Surgery continues to evolve as a model for primary and tertiary patient care, integrating all aspects of surgical management including inpatient, ambulatory, and emergency services. The faculty will provide the surgical resident with a progressively graded curriculum of study including clinical and research experience under close guidance and supervision. The surgical resident will acquire a broad understanding of disease biology as it relates to disorders of a surgical nature and the technical knowledge and skills appropriate to completely manage patients with surgical diseases. The resident will also develop professional skills and receive system-based training in small group sessions. Perelman Department of Emergency Medicine                                                                                  Home   Patient Care   Education   Research   Courses   Our People   Make a Donation                                  Home Education Residency            Print  Email               - A + A                                         Education        open/close   Fellowships     open/close   Residency  Leadership   Overview   Curriculum   Training Sites   Research   Resident Life   Rotation Schedule   Application   Our Residents       open/close   Visiting Resident Medical Toxicology Rotation     open/close   Medical Students     open/close   Undergraduates                                                                      Residency                                                      Message from the Director   Welcome to the exciting and fulfilling world of Emergency Medicine at NYU/Bellevue. Our highest priority is to ensure exceptional patient care for an incredibly diverse and underserved population while training Emergency Medicine residents to become outstanding physicians, both clinically and academically, in the vibrant and multicultural setting of New York City.   The Emergency Medicine Residency at NYU/Bellevue is a four-year program dedicated to training well-rounded physicians who learn to not only become superior clinicians, but also learn to become educators, researchers, and leaders in Emergency Medicine.  Residents are exposed to tremendous diversity in clinical pathology and patient populations by rotating at three hospital centers all along First Avenue: Bellevue Hospital Center, NYU’s Tisch Hospital, and the Manhattan VA Hospital.   As a resident here, you will care for patients who are diplomats and CEOs as well as those suffering from mental illness, substance abuse, and homelessness. You will experience life a different way every day as you care for patients from all over the world and from all socioeconomic strata who seek your assistance. You will be an integral part of the public health of the community in New York City.   Residents are given graded responsibility as they progress through the program with an emphasis on teaching. Residents are supervised and taught by board-certified Emergency Medicine physicians in a collegial and enthusiastic environment. Our goal is to raise the level of emergency care across the country and across the world.   Thank you for your interest in our program and website.  Please feel free to contact us with any questions or comments about our residency.   Sincerely,   Jeffrey Manko, MD  Program Director  Emergency Medicine Residency  NYU/Bellevue Medical Center                                                                                         NYU Langone Medical Center       Student Login       Library                 Policies & Disclaimers
